examples: There are only two cookies left.
two of Sweden’s top financial experts
Ten people were invited but only two turned up.
Can you lend me two dollars?
a two-month contract
Look at page two.
Two and seven is nine.
Three twos are six.
I can't read your writing—is this meant to be a two?
The bulbs are planted in twos or threes (= groups of two or three).
We moved to America when I was two (= two years old).
Shall we meet at two (= at two o'clock), then?

meanings.def: to be unable to decide what you think about somebody/something, or whether to do something or not
examples: I was in two minds about the book (= I didn't know if I liked it or not).
She's in two minds about accepting his invitation.

meanings.def: one or a few days, moments, pounds, etc.
examples: May I borrow it for a day or two?

meanings.def: to fail to be or to get either of two choices, both of which would have been acceptable
in or into two pieces or halves
examples: He broke the bar of chocolate in two and gave me half.

meanings.def: two or three at a time; in small numbers
examples: People arrived in twos and threes.
We’ll be there in a couple of shakes.

meanings.def: one person cannot be completely responsible for something
examples: You can't put all the blame on him. It takes two to make a marriage.

meanings.def: used to say that two people or groups, and not just one, are responsible for something that has happened (usually something bad)
to be very poor, stupid, etc.
to guess the truth from what you see, hear, etc.
examples: He's inclined to put two and two together and make five (= reaches the wrong conclusion from what he sees, hears, etc.).

meanings.def: I am in the same position or I agree with you
examples: ‘I'm tired!’ ‘That makes two of us!’

meanings.def: very common and therefore not valuable
examples: Teachers of history are ten a penny.

meanings.def: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation

idioms.idiom: be in two minds about something/about doing something
idioms.def: to be unable to decide what you think about somebody/something, or whether to do something or not
examples: I was in two minds about the book (= I didn't know if I liked it or not).
She's in two minds about accepting his invitation.

idioms.idiom: a day, moment, pound, etc. or two
idioms.def: one or a few days, moments, pounds, etc.
examples: May I borrow it for a day or two?

idioms.def: to fail to be or to get either of two choices, both of which would have been acceptable
in or into two pieces or halves
examples: He broke the bar of chocolate in two and gave me half.

idioms.def: two or three at a time; in small numbers
examples: People arrived in twos and threes.

idioms.idiom: in two shakes | in a couple of shakes
examples: We’ll be there in a couple of shakes.

idioms.idiom: it takes two to do something
idioms.def: one person cannot be completely responsible for something
examples: You can't put all the blame on him. It takes two to make a marriage.

idioms.def: used to say that two people or groups, and not just one, are responsible for something that has happened (usually something bad)

idioms.idiom: not have two cents, pennies, brain cells, etc. to rub together
idioms.def: to be very poor, stupid, etc.
to guess the truth from what you see, hear, etc.
examples: He's inclined to put two and two together and make five (= reaches the wrong conclusion from what he sees, hears, etc.).

idioms.def: I am in the same position or I agree with you
examples: ‘I'm tired!’ ‘That makes two of us!’

idioms.def: very common and therefore not valuable
examples: Teachers of history are ten a penny.

idioms.idiom: two sides of the same coin
idioms.def: used to talk about two ways of looking at the same situation
